data.title: CoCo
data.text: Love the CoCo space. I once worked in the building and was quite sad when the trading floor closed. So glad they repurposed it.

data.title: A small pocket of the past at the Minneapolis Grain Exchange
data.text: Next time you're downtown Minneapolis pop in to the Minneapolis Grain Exchange. Admire the terra-cotta exterior then head to the 4th floor observation gallery to view the historic trading floor. The huge windows were designed to let in enough natural light to allow the "Cash Market" traders to easily rate the qualityt of sample pans of wheat, oats,  and barley. In the 'futures' pit the open-out-cry trading system has been replace with electronic trading but you can almost hear the calls of "Dec Wheat-a-quarter." The price board was state of the art back in the early 1980s, and a bit of the old chalk board remains where once comely women perched on narrow platforms to write in prices. If you're a business history buff it's defintely worth a stop. Even the less interested might enjoy a brief glance at a by-gone era.

data.title: Neat old building
data.text:
I like to tour old buildings, looking at the materials that were used and how they have faired over the years.

The grain exchange is an office building with public access limited to lobby, stairwell, elevator and hallways.  There is a cafeteria. 

It's worth a quick walkthru, but no more then a few minutes.

data.title: Now CoCo coworking space
data.text: Beautiful architecture and the former trading floor is now CoCo coworking space - Great place to network and work

data.title: Edwardo's Pizza
data.text: Edwardo's Pizza was in this building many years ago. They had the best stuff pizza offered under the sun. The were on the main floor. My mother in Maple Grove would even request a pizza from there if I was in the city. Too bad it's gone now..

data.title: Some beautiful woodcraft and construction put to new use.
data.text: Hated to see the floor shut down. There is something exciting about the business done on the floor of any exchange. so another good-bye to an era.  Happy and hoping to see re-purpose take place with attention to preserving the gorgeous details past craftsman created to last forever....

data.title: Commanding architecture with graceful ornamentation...
data.text:
The best way to see Minneapolis’s building architectural style like the Grain Exchange is to just put on a comfy pair of shoes, take a bottle of water, arm yourself with a good descriptive map, remember to look up and get walking! That’s exactly the way we did most parts of the downtown core and we were lucky to have a fine day as there are few buildings with cover (except the skywalks).

One of many landmark buildings in Minneapolis, the Grain Exchange Building is low rise, multi - level and has that uniformity seen everywhere around the city. In fact seen at a distance they all look the same and reminded us of historical buildings in Chicago.
 
As  ‘amateur building tourists ‘ we didn’t know what the ‘Sullivanesque’ style really was so we had to look it up.The Grain Exchange building is exactly that and basically in the style favoured by Louis Sullivan and his development of large scale, interior steel framed commercial and office buildings.

Rising ten stories, built of granite, brick and terra cotta it was constructed before the turn of the old century. Several additional facilities were added after 1900 when Minnesota became the largest primary wheat market in the world.

Like most of the historical buildings throughout this city we thought this one was rather square and modular however, viewed up close and also from across the street it seemed dignified and commanding - if you can call a style that! 
It’s the external ornamentation and columns that adds gentility to the overall plainness of the style.

We had a great time exploring the historical buildings including this one in Minneapolis!

Enjoy your experience too!

data.title: Vintage 1902 Commercial building in Minneapolis
data.text: I was there yesterday and not so sure what the other poster was talking about.  I was up on the 4th floor where the trading floor was and saw the big board that is in the photo.  The building is worth a look around, but then there are a lot of buildings like that in downtown Minneapolis.  "When you walk in the doors of the Main Building, the first thing you notice is the classic combination of marble, brass and brick combined with intricately designed stonework and pilasters formed with buff colored terra cotta stonework."  from the commercial brochure for the building.
